general_overview: Bangladesh’s internet journey began in the early 1990s with limited dial-up email services via bulletin board systems. The first full internet service using a VSAT satellite link was launched in June 1996 [oai_citation_attribution:0‡bcs.org.bd](https://bcs.org.bd/en/blog/evolution-of-the-internet-in-bangladesh#:~:text=that%20year%20with%20offline%20emailing,technology%20to%20provide%20Internet%20service), when the government’s telecom authority (then BTTB) licensed the country’s first private Internet Service Providers (ISPs) [oai_citation_attribution:1‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_in_Bangladesh#:~:text=In%20June%201996%20the%20first,2). In the late 1990s and early 2000s, internet access was mostly through slow dial-up connections; nevertheless, the ISP industry grew rapidly under liberalized policies, reaching over 180 registered ISPs by 2005 [oai_citation_attribution:2‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_in_Bangladesh#:~:text=In%20June%201996%20the%20first,2). A major milestone came in May 2006 when Bangladesh connected to its first submarine fiber-optic cable, the SEA-ME-WE 4 consortium, via a landing station at Cox’s Bazar [oai_citation_attribution:3‡bcs.org.bd](https://bcs.org.bd/en/blog/evolution-of-the-internet-in-bangladesh#:~:text=Internet%2C%20all%20of%20a%20sudden,transmission%20speeds%20intended%20to%20accommodate). This significantly increased the country’s bandwidth and reduced dependence on costly satellite links. Mobile internet began around 2005 with GPRS/EDGE on 2G networks [oai_citation_attribution:4‡bcs.org.bd](https://bcs.org.bd/en/blog/evolution-of-the-internet-in-bangladesh#:~:text=the%20most%20remarkable%20years%20in,changer%20after%20Bangladesh%20got%20connected), but truly accelerated after 3G services launched in 2013 and 4G in 2018, bringing broadband to all 64 districts. As a result, internet usage soared: by March 2021 Bangladesh had about 116 million internet subscribers (roughly 70% of the population) [oai_citation_attribution:5‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_in_Bangladesh#:~:text=The%20Internet%20in%20Bangladesh%20has,started%20the%204G%20network%20service). By the end of 2023, users surpassed 131 million, the vast majority on mobile devices (118.5 million mobile data users) versus around 12.9 million fixed broadband subscribers [oai_citation_attribution:6‡wicinternet.org](https://www.wicinternet.org/2024-02/18/c_990134.htm#:~:text=The%20Bangladesh%20Telecommunication%20Regulatory%20Commission,88%20million%20broadband%20internet%20users). Today, Bangladesh’s internet ecosystem is one of the largest among developing nations, supported by several submarine cables, nationwide fiber-optic networks, and a growing emphasis on digital services under the “Digital Bangladesh” initiative.

infrastructure.regulator: Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission (BTRC) – Established in 2002 under the Telecom Act 2001 as the independent regulator for telecom and internet services [oai_citation_attribution:30‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Bangladesh#:~:text=,into%20Bangladesh%20Telecommunications%20Company%20Limited). BTRC issues licenses (ISP, mobile, IIG, etc.), allocates spectrum, and oversees industry compliance.
infrastructure.bsccl: Bangladesh Submarine Cable Company Ltd (BSCCL) – Formed in July 2008 to manage and operate international submarine cable connectivity [oai_citation_attribution:31‡en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Bangladesh#:~:text=%2A%202005%3A%20Egypt,IPTSP%29%20Operators%20launched). BSCCL owns Bangladesh’s stakes in the SEA-ME-WE 4 and 5 undersea cables, and is deploying the upcoming SEA-ME-WE 6, providing the country with bandwidth and redundancy.
infrastructure.major_isps: Major ISPs – The four mobile network operators (Grameenphone, Robi Axiata, Banglalink, Teletalk) provide the bulk of internet access, together serving over 118 million mobile data users [oai_citation_attribution:32‡wicinternet.org](https://www.wicinternet.org/2024-02/18/c_990134.htm#:~:text=The%20Bangladesh%20Telecommunication%20Regulatory%20Commission,88%20million%20broadband%20internet%20users). In the fixed broadband sector, hundreds of ISPs (often via fiber or wireless last-mile) serve ~13 million subscribers; top nationwide ISPs include those under the ISP Association of Bangladesh (ISPAB).

infrastructure.fiber_optic_network: Fiber-Optic Network – Nationwide fiber connectivity has expanded rapidly. Two private Nationwide Telecommunication Transmission Network (NTTN) operators (Fiber@Home and Summit Communications, licensed 2009) built extensive fiber backbones linking all districts and towns [oai_citation_attribution:35‡bcs.org.bd](https://bcs.org.bd/en/blog/evolution-of-the-internet-in-bangladesh#:~:text=reality%2C%20they%20were%20bound%20to,There%20was%20no%20redundancy). Along with fibers from power utilities and BTCL, Bangladesh has tens of thousands of kilometers of fiber optics, reaching even rural union parishads. By 2022, fiber-based broadband access was extended to over 100,000 rural institutions under government projects [oai_citation_attribution:36‡pressxpress.org](https://pressxpress.org/2023/11/02/unveiling-btrcs-new-broadband-policy/#:~:text=However%2C%20as%20part%20of%20the,were%20slated%20to%20receive%20enhanced).

digital_inclusion.description: A government vision to transform the country through ICT by the year 2021. It prioritized expanding internet connectivity, e-governance, IT education, and digital services to achieve middle-income status. This agenda drove numerous projects in infrastructure, connectivity, and digital literacy.

One-stop service outlets at the union (village council) level. In November 2010, 4,501 Union Information and Service Centres were launched nationwide [oai_citation_attribution:37‡undp.org](https://www.undp.org/bangladesh/publications/fostering-transformation-through-digital-centre#:~:text=) – later termed UDCs – each staffed by local entrepreneurs. They provide rural citizens access to online government services, information, internet, mobile banking, and digital training, bridging the rural-urban digital divide.

Services like bKash (launched in 2011) and others have harnessed the widespread mobile internet to enable mobile banking, payments, and money transfers. By offering financial services via basic mobile phones, these initiatives have brought millions of unbanked people (especially in rural areas) into the formal financial system, exemplifying the power of digital inclusion.

A multi-phase government program (supported by the World Bank) aimed at building ICT infrastructure and connectivity. Phase III (2017–2022) focused on last-mile connectivity: it established broadband internet connections in 109,244 rural government offices (schools, clinics, Union Parishads, etc.) [oai_citation_attribution:38‡pressxpress.org](https://pressxpress.org/2023/11/02/unveiling-btrcs-new-broadband-policy/#:~:text=However%2C%20as%20part%20of%20the,were%20slated%20to%20receive%20enhanced), ensuring that public services like healthcare, education, and agriculture advisories are accessible online even in remote areas.

Bangladesh introduced numerous e-governance services to capitalize on growing internet access. A national e-Service portal (covering 25,000+ government websites) was rolled out, and systems like online tax filing, electronic public procurement, telemedicine platforms, digital land records, and mobile court apps were implemented. These efforts, often supported by the Access to Information (a2i) program, aim to make public services more transparent, efficient, and inclusive.
